node.title: Fed winds back bond buying as inflation soars, but ASX set to rise
node.alt: A blurred photo of the share trading boards at the Australian stock exchange
node.description: Global markets are soaring, as the US Federal Reserve moves to wind back economic stimulus brought in to tackle the pandemic downturn.
node.content: ["Global markets are soaring, as the US Federal Reserve moves to wind back economic stimulus brought in to tackle the pandemic downturn.", "The Fed says it'll end its COVID-era bond purchases in March.", "That's earlier than forecast and paves the way for interest rates to be increased by the end of 2022.", "It comes as the US battles the highest level of inflation \u2014\u00a0or price rises \u2014 it has seen in decades.", "At 7:30am AEDT, Wall Street was reacting positively.", "The Dow was soaring on the news with a gain of 1 per cent, while the S&P and Nasdaq were even higher at 1.4 and 1.9 per cent respectively.", "ASX 200 futures were also up 0.3 per cent, which was a turn on sentiment from just a few hours previously.", "\"The US dollar temporarily jumped after the FOMC delivered a hawkish policy announcement, though is now below its pre\u2011FOMC level,\" ANZ noted.", "\"The US/AUD was quick to regain its post\u2011FOMC losses and is trading near 0.7135.\u00a0 Nevertheless, ongoing volatility is possible.\"", "More to come."]
